Text saved: Two men looked at the land.
They looked at the north part of the land.
The land was very, very big.
They could not see the end.
It was hard to see the fences.
The fences were very far away.

A teenage boy can get bored and angry.
But he could not run away from this place.
He could not walk away.

Sam looked at the biggest horse.
The horse was hitting the ground with its big feet.
Sam thought, "Can the boy ride a horse?"
A good rider could make a lot of problems here.
This place was far from other people.
But maybe there was a bigger problem.
A boy who did not know about horses could have more trouble.
Especially if he wanted to run away from his father.

The sentence structure is appropriately simple for A2, but this does not excuse the critical failure to preserve the original meaning.

Correction Mandate:
- Rephrase to restore the comparative meaning. The concept of 'even more trouble' must be clearly communicated.
- Replace the B1 word 'rider'. Use an A2 phrase such as 'a person who can ride a horse'.
- The simplification was too aggressive, resulting in a loss of the core message. The text must be rewritten to maintain the original's central conflict.
